intro: Lepidaploa aurea, commonly known as the golden lepidaploa, is a flowering plant native to the Andes Mountains of South America. It belongs to the family Apiaceae, which includes carrots and parsley, and is characterized by its finely divided, fern-like leaves. The plant produces small, yellowish flowers that bloom in clusters, often attracting pollinators such as bees and butterflies. Lepidaploa aurea is typically found in moist, shaded environments, growing in rocky or forested areas. Its unique morphology and habitat make it an interesting subject for botanical study.
